summary_reasoning: The report contains at least four clear company-specific syntheses and one original thesis, all linking mechanisms, numbers, and catalysts to Goldman Sachs’ trajectory. Notable syntheses include: stress-test outcomes and SCB reductions translating into excess capital returns; the GBM ecosystem dynamic (trading + investment banking) yielding consolidated ROE stability and future 15% ROE; leverage/timeline contingencies tied to principal investment winddown; and an investment banking rebound driven by dry powder plus falling rates with trading normalization and AWM monetization. The original thesis posits technology-driven bargaining power shifting toward brands, supporting a quantified path to a 30% compensation ratio, 60% efficiency by decade-end, and 490 bps margin expansion. Insights are decision-relevant, with explicit timelines (end-2026 exit of principal investments, decade-end margin targets), quantified impacts (1.5 ppt SCB drop for GS, 5% of market cap excess capital), and segment growth assumptions. While some boilerplate appears, most analysis goes beyond restating public filings, integrating mechanisms and catalysts with Goldman-specific data. Valuation drivers are novel and specific, avoiding a generic DCF.

insights_classified.text: We estimate stress capital buffers will fall by ~1.5 ppt for Goldman; banks could hold ~5% of market cap in excess capital for return.
Investments in technology shift power toward brands, enabling a 30% compensation ratio and 60% efficiency by decade-end; ~490 bps margin expansion.
GBM ecosystem: trading near cost of capital but strengthens IB; consolidated GBM averaged 14% ROE and is projected at 15% over the next decade.
Alternative sponsors’ dry powder + falling rates → IB rebound; trading to normalize lower; AWM fund monetization lifts incentive fees over next few years.
Leverage to >15x by decade-end contingent on exiting principal investments by 2026 and better stress tests, releasing excess capital to shareholders.
UHNW wealth business: avg account $70m; 54% SMA wrappers; high retention implies switching costs and supports durable growth.
